Award.AwardTitle: G8 Initiative: SmartCoat: Multiscale Smart Coatings with Sustained Anticorrosive Action

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This NSF award funds U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by the G8 Research Councils Initiative "Structural Bamboo Products." This is a pilot collaboration among the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Canadian National Sciences and Engineering Research Council (NSERC), the French Agence Nationale de la Recherche (ANR), the German Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG), the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS), the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (RFBR),and the United Kingdom Research Councils (RCUK), supporting collaborative research projects selected on a competitive basis that are comprised of researchers from at least three of the partner countries.

This research award provides funding for the development of materials and techniques to produce non-toxic, biocompatible, composite materials that release environmentally-friendly and application-specific anticorrosion, antimicrobial, and antifouling agents upon demand and in a sustained fashion. Three types of non-toxic multiscale micro/nano containers will be investigated so that application-specific solutions with multiple levels of protection can be offered. The first level of protection will be provided by the incorporation of nanotraps (nanoparticles that absorb aggressive/corrosive species). The second level will trigger the release of polymerizable precursors entrapped in nanocapsules. The highest level of protection will be based on encapsulation of chemical and biological corrosion inhibitors acting on demand to suppress degradation in open defects. The research program includes the synergistic cooperation between experiments and computational modeling, making it possible to fine-tune and optimize the multi-scale container systems to specific design and performance targets. The composed containers will be incorporated into materials already existing to protect civil and industrial infrastructure (e.g., paints, varnishes, waxes or other coatings).

If successful, the results of this research will lead to improvements in the operating lifetime of industrial materials. The primary goal of this work is to develop generalized methods and design criteria for encapsulation of anticorrosion, antimicrobial, or self-healing agents and methods to apply them in coatings that enable a release upon demand in response to a defined trigger. These design criteria may include solvents or other environmental conditions maximizing efficiency of encapsulation, minimizing the production time, minimizing the energy required for the process, minimizing the response time of the stimulated release, or maximizing the stability of the finalized coatings. Determining the process parameters to achieve these objectives will help to reduce the cost and improve the performance of the coatings. The work will also contribute to the basic understanding of encapsulation and responsive materials. Ultimately, sustained protection of materials from chemical and biological degradation (corrosion) and mechanical destruction using these materials will have tremendous economic and social benefits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work was a small part of a larger effort that focused on general approaches to apply coatings that protect materials from corrosion while avoiding environmental pollution. Our greater team efforts leveraged unique international capabilities in self-assembled nanocoatings with embedded micro/nanocontainers to enhance properties (mechanical strength, sustained/on-demand release of corrosion inhibitors, and optical damage indicators).

The narrow focus of the work at Texas A&M was on the latter aspect, sensor functionality, although our fabrication approaches for nanocontainers are also applicable to the encapsulation and release of anticorrosives, etc. Here, we aimed primarily to design micro/nanoscale particles that exhibit a change in a measurable optical property upon exposure to harsh conditions (extreme low oxygen, pH, reacive oxygen species such as peroxide).  These materials were developed using phosphors for oxygen sensing and noble metal nanoparticles for pH and peroxide sensing. We evaluated the responsiveness of these materials, as well as their stability over time and reversible behavior. In addition, we showed that the oxygen and pH indicators could also be used to monitor the progress of enzymatic reactions that either consume or produce those species.

Our major activities involved investigating various approaches to create coatings with optical damage indication, including self-assembled Bragg reflectors using a combination of natural pH-sensitive polyelectrolytes and inorganic nanoparticles. These were found to be too inconsistent in quality and unstable for reliable use. Therefore, most effort was devoted to design, fabrication, and testing of fluorescent and Raman scattering-based sensors for oxygen, pH, and peroxide.

Specific Objectives:

1) Develop polymeric micro/nano-encapsulated fluorescent/phosphorescent sensors for oxygen, pH, and peroxide

2) Enhancement of stability and diffusion control/tuning of molecular-weight cutoff for capsules

3) Development of new encapsulated pH sensors based on surface enhanced Raman scattering using metallic nanomaterials

4) Evaluate stability and sensitivity of materials to environmental factors (temperature, nonspecific background changes, degradation by enzymes, etc)

Significant Results:
1) Development of reliable processes for production of microcapsules, starting with microtemplate fabrication.

2) We investigated methods of enhancing capsule/sensor stability and diffusion control/tuning, comparing crosslinkers and showing effective adjustment of behavior with short, mild treatments.

3) Investigation of a new sensing paradigm using micoencapsulated SERS-active nanomaterials with surface fuctionalization to achieve desired sensing behavior (pH). In what we believe is a completely novel appoach to sensing, we have recently proven fully-reversible change in Raman scattering in response to pH changes. We believe this approach may be extremely useful in identifying locations of acid attack in a material/coating.  The Raman measurement is very sensitive, but requires some instrumentation. We believe this may possibly be modified to achieve a visual readout using localized surface plasmon resonance effect based on local, reversible aggregation of metallic nanoparticles.

4) Demonstration that co-encapsulated nanoclusters and fluospheres provide ratiometric changes in response to peroxide; these exhibits low photobleaching, protection against degradation and minimal sensitivity to pH changes. 

The SERS pH sensing work was reported at IEEE SENSORS conference (2015) and ACS (2016).  A full-length manuscript on pH sensing using metal nanoparticles inside of microcapsules was published in IEEE Sensors Journal.  The work on fluorescent peroxide sensors has been submitted to Biosensors and Bioelectronics and revision was requested. The revised version is currently under consideration. Additional papers on oxygen and glucose sensors that also benefited from this work but primarily impacted other projects were also published as journal papers and conferences presentations.

As a result of the US-Japan partnership, McShane worked at NIMS (Japan) for 10 weeks in Summer 2015. hosted NIMS researcher (Huynh Thien Ngo, PhD) during winter 2015-2016. Two of McShane's PhD students worked at NIMS in Summer 2016 for 3-month research programs.  There are ongoing discussions for a TAMU undergraduate to travel to NIMS for research in summer 2017.
